data.event: The county was formed in 1810, becoming Kentucky's 53rd county.
A 1932 survey found nine sites, many of which were a group of shell mounds, including the Carlston Annis and DeWeese Shell Mounds.
The area now known as Butler County was first settled by the families of Richard C. Dellium and James Forgy, who founded a town called Berry's Lick.

event.title: January 18, 1810, the Kentucky General Assembly created

data.event: On January 18, 1810, the Kentucky General Assembly created Butler County from portions of Logan and Ohio counties.

event.title: died at the Battle of the Wabash in 1791

data.event: The new county was named for Major General Richard Butler, who died at the Battle of the Wabash in 1791.
The Confederate-Union Veterans' Monument in Morgantown, a zinc monument, was dedicated in 1907 on the Butler County Courthouse lawn.
